[[Birkhoff Prize]] (1994) |religion = |footnotes = |signature = }} '''Sathamangalam Ranga Iyengar Srinivasa Varadhan''' [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (born 2 January 1940) is an [[Indian American]] [[mathematician]] who is known for his fundamental contributions to [[probability theory]] and in particular for creating a unified theory of large deviations.{{cite web|last=Ramachandran|first=R.|title=Science of chance|url=http://frontlineonnet.com/fl2407/stories/20070420001909700.htm|work=Frontline|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20071211145135/http://www.frontlineonnet.com/fl2407/stories/20070420001909700.htm|archivedate=11 December 2007|location=India|date=7–20 April 2007}} Since 2009 he has been one of the Jury Chairs for the [[Infosys Prize]] in the discipline of [[Mathematical Sciences]].[http://www.infosys-science-foundation.com/prize/jury/2015/index.asp Jury chairs by year] ==Early life and education== Srinivasa Varadhan, known also as Raghu to friends, was born in [[Chennai]] (previously [[Madras]]) in 1940.[http://gonitsora.com/interview-with-srinivasa-varadhan/ Interview with Srinivasa Varadhan], http://gonitsora.com Varadhan received his undergraduate degree in 1959 from [[University of Madras|Presidency College, Madras]], and then moved to the [[Indian Statistical Institute]] in [[Kolkata]]. He was one of the "famous four" (the others were [[R. Ranga Rao]], [[K. R. Parthasarathy (probabilist)|K. R. Parthasarathy]], and [[Veeravalli S. Varadarajan]] ) in [[Indian Statistical Institute|ISI]] during 1956-1963.{{cite web|last=Kalyan Bidhan Sinha and B. V. Rajarama Bhat|title=S. R. Srinivasa Varadhan|url=https://www.math.lsu.edu/cosa/6-1-00%5Bpartha%5D.pdf|publisher=[[Louisiana State University]]}} He received his doctorate from [[Indian Statistical Institute|ISI]] in 1963 under [[C. R. Rao]],{{MathGenealogy|id=33923}}[http://www.isical.ac.in/~deanweb/ALU_DEGR.HTM List of degree / diploma / certificate recipients of ISI], web site at the [[Indian Statistical Institute]], accessed 22 March 2007. who arranged for [[Andrey Kolmogorov]] to be present at Varadhan's thesis defense.[http://www.allvoices.com/people/S._R._Srinivasa_Varadhan S. R. Srinivasa Varadhan's Biography], Allvoices, accessed 1 August 2010. Since 1963, he has worked at the [[Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences]] at [[New York University]], where he was at first a postdoctoral fellow (1963–66), strongly recommended by [[Monroe D. Donsker]]. Here he met [[Daniel Stroock]], who became a close colleague and co-author. In an article in the ''Notices of the American Mathematical Society'', Stroock recalls these early years: {{Quotation|Varadhan, whom everyone calls Raghu, came to these shores from his native India in the fall of 1963. He arrived by plane at Idlewild Airport and proceeded to Manhattan by bus. His destination was that famous institution with the modest name, The Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, where he had been given a postdoctoral fellowship. Varadhan was assigned to one of the many windowless offices in the Courant building, which used to be a hat factory. Yet despite the somewhat humble surroundings, from these offices flowed a remarkably large fraction of the postwar mathematics of which America is justly proud.}} Varadhan is currently a professor at the Courant Institute.[http://www.ams.org/notices/199611/comm-steele.pdf Announcement of the] 1996 [[Steele Prize]]s at the [[American Mathematical Society]] web site, accessed 21 February 2007.Srinivasa Varadhan is known as S R S Varadhan for short and Raghu to his friends and colleagues. His father, Ranga Iyengar, was a science teacher who became the Principal of the Board High School in Ponneri [http://www.abelprisen.no/nedlastning/2007/biography_en.pdf Biography] (PDF), from the [[Abel Prize]] web site, accessed 22 March 2007. He is known for his work with [[Daniel W. Stroock]] on [[diffusion process]]es, and for his work on [[large deviations]] with [[Monroe D. Donsker]]. Varadhan is married to Vasundra Varadhan who is also an academic (in media studies in the [[Gallatin School of Individualized Study]]). They have two sons, one of whom died in the [[September 11 attacks]] in 2001. His other son, Ashok, is an executive at [[Goldman Sachs]] in [[New York City]].{{cite web|url=http://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/02/10/goldman-promotes-ashok-varadhan-to-co-head-of-securities/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0 |title=Goldman Promotes Ashok Varadhan to Co-Head of Securities |publisher=New York Times Dealbook |date=2014-02-10}} ==Awards and honours== Varadhan's awards and honours include the [[National Medal of Science]] (2010) from President [[Barack Obama]], "the highest honor bestowed by the [[United States government]] on scientists, engineers and inventors".{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2011/09/27/president-obama-honors-nation-s-top-scientists-and-innovators |title=President Obama Honors Nation’s Top Scientists and Innovators |publisher=[[Executive Office of the President of the United States|The White House]]|date=27 September 2011 |accessdate=28 September 2011}} He received also the [[Birkhoff Prize]] (1994), the Margaret and Herman Sokol Award of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences, New York University (1995), and the [[Leroy P. Steele Prize for Seminal Contribution to Research]] (1996) from the [[American Mathematical Society]], awarded for his work with [[Daniel W. Stroock]] on [[diffusion process]]es.{{cite journal|url=http://www.ams.org/notices/199611/comm-steele.pdf |title=1996 Steele Prizes |journal=[[Notices of the American Mathematical Society]] |volume=43 |issue=11 |pages=1340–1347 |date=November 1996 |accessdate=29 September 2011}} He was awarded the [[Abel Prize]] in 2007 for his work on [[large deviations]] with [[Monroe D. Donsker]].[http://www.abelprisen.no/nedlastning/2007/citation_en.pdf Citation for the Abel Prize] (PDF), accessed 22 March 2007. In 2008, the Government of India awarded him the [[Padma Bhushan]].{{cite web | url=http://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/LST-PDAWD-2013.pdf | title=Padma Awards | publisher=Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India | date=2015 | accessdate=July 21, 2015}} He also has two honorary degrees from Université Pierre et Marie Curie in Paris (2003) and from Indian Statistical Institute in Kolkata, India (2004). Varadhan is a member of the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|U.S. National Academy of Sciences]] (1995),{{cite web|url=http://www.nasonline.org/site/Dir?sid=1011&view=basic&pg=srch |title=NAS Membership Directory |publisher=[[United States National Academy of Sciences|U.S. National Academy of Sciences]] |accessdate=10 June 2011}} Search with Last Name is "Varadhan". and the [[Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters]] (2009).{{cite web|url=http://www.dnva.no/c26849/artikkel/vis.html?tid=40116|title=Gruppe 1: Matematiske fag|publisher=[[Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters]]|language=Norwegian|accessdate=10 June 2011}} He was elected to Fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] (1988),{{cite web|title=Book of Members, 1780-2010: Chapter V|url=http://www.amacad.org/publications/BookofMembers/ChapterV.pdf|publisher=[[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]]|accessdate=10 June 2011}} the [[Third World Academy of Sciences]] (1988), the [[Institute of Mathematical Statistics]] (1991), the [[Royal Society]] (1998),{{cite web|url=http://royalsociety.org/uploadedFiles/Royal_Society_Content/about-us/fellowship/Fellows_and_Foreign_Members.pdf |title=Fellows of the Royal Society |publisher=[[Royal Society]] |accessdate=10 June 2011}} the [[Indian Academy of Sciences]] (2004), the [[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics]] (2009),{{cite web|url=http://fellows.siam.org/index.php?sort=year&value=2009 |title=SIAM Fellows: Class of 2009 |publisher=[[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics]] |accessdate=10 June 2011}} and the [[American Mathematical Society]] (2012).[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society], retrieved 2013-08-28. ==Quotes== * "If you can write it down, it's measurable!"...... ==Selected publications== *''Convolution Properties of Distributions on Topological Groups''.
